questions.text:
A 27-year-old female patient was rushed to the ER for high fever and shortness of breath. Her symptoms started a week before presentation with diarrhea, followed by high-grade fever for three days. She has a recent history of traveling to Phuket for her honeymoon 3 weeks before. Her husband has no symptoms. On clinical examination, bilateral crepitations were heard. She also had skin ulcers, as shown in the photo.

What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Melioidosis, also known as Vietnam time bomb disease, is an endemic infection in Southeast Asia caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, and presents with pneumonia, fever, and characteristic skin ulcers.

  • This patient shows acute febrile illness, pulmonary involvement, and skin ulcers after travel to an endemic region (Phuket, Thailand), strongly suggesting melioidosis.
  • The disease is known as the "Vietnam time bomb" due to its long latent phase and reactivation years later.
  • Causative organism:
    • Burkholderia pseudomallei, a gram-negative, motile bacillus found in soil and water in Southeast Asia and northern Australia.
  • Clinical features:
    • Fever, malaise
    • Pneumonia with bilateral crepitations
    • Characteristic cutaneous ulcers or abscesses
    • Can progress to septicemia
  • Risk factors:
    • Diabetes mellitus, renal disease, travel to endemic areas, and occupational exposure to soil.
  • Diagnosis is via culture of blood, sputum, or pus.
    • Empiric therapy includes ceftazidime or meropenem, followed by eradication therapy with TMP-SMX.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): TB rarely presents acutely with diarrhea and skin ulcers; the time course and exposure history point toward melioidosis.

Cutaneous cryptococcosis (Option C): Seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV), not commonly associated with pulmonary symptoms and diarrhea in immunocompetent travelers.

Ecthyma gangrenosum (Option D): Typically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa in neutropenic patients; does not explain the travel history or respiratory findings.

questions.text: Following the appearance on Gram staining is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Haemophilus influenzae is a pleomorphic, tiny gram-negative coccobacillus that often requires special media (like chocolate agar) and does not exhibit the typical gram-negative bacilli appearance seen in the others.

  • The question focuses on the Gram stain morphology of different Gram-negative organisms.
  • All the organisms listed are gram-negative, but the appearance on a gram stain varies based on size, shape, and pleomorphism.
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei: Shows a safety pin appearance due to bipolar staining with methylene blue or Wayson stain. (Option A ruled out)
    • It is a motile, gram-negative rod commonly seen in melioidosis.
  • Yersinia pestis: Also shows bipolar staining (safety pin appearance), especially with Wayson stain. (Option B ruled out)
    • A gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus: Gram-negative, curved/comma-shaped bacillus seen in Gram staining. (Option C ruled out)
  • Haemophilus influenzae: Does NOT show typical safety-pin or curved rod morphology.
    • Instead, it appears as a very small pleomorphic gram-negative coccobacilli, often faint or poorly stained, and may be missed without enriched media.

choices.text: Glanders - nasal discharge and ulcers in the nasal septum; Farcy - skin lesions and lymph node involvement
Glanders - skin lesions and lymph node involvement; Farcy - nasal discharge and ulcers in the nasal septum
Glanders - skin lesions only; Farcy - ulceration in the nasal septum
Both Glanders and Farcy are synonymous

questions.text: While reading a case report of infections caused by Burkholderia mallei, you come across terms like Glander's disease and Farcy caused by it in horses. These terms refer to which of the following, respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glanders is the respiratory form of Burkholderia mallei infection with nasal discharge and ulceration, while Farcy refers to the cutaneous form with skin nodules and lymphadenitis.

  • Burkholderia mallei is the causative agent of glanders, a zoonotic infection that primarily affects horses, mules, and donkeys.
  • It can also infect humans, especially those in close contact with infected animals.
  • Glanders disease occurs in two major forms:
    • Respiratory/Nasal form (Glanders):
      • Presents with fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge, and ulcers on the nasal septum and respiratory tract.
      • The term "glanders" typically refers to this nasal form of the disease.
    • Cutaneous form (Farcy):
      • Characterized by ulcers, nodules, and suppurative lymphadenitis along the skin and lymphatic channels.
      • The nodules tend to follow lymphatics in a chain-like pattern, giving a characteristic "string-of-pearls" appearance.
  • Both forms can be fatal if not promptly treated.
  • Human infection is characterized by:
    • Local skin nodules and lymphadenitis (if transmitted by inoculation).
    • Pneumonia, ulceration of the trachea, and sepsis (if transmitted by inhalation).

questions.text: In a Microbiology laboratory, you were asked to differentiate Burkholderia pseudomallei and Burkholderia mallei based on biochemical properties. Which of the following tests would be used for the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The oxidase test helps differentiate Burkholderia pseudomallei (oxidase positive) from Burkholderia mallei (oxidase variable or weakly positive).

  • Burkholderia pseudomallei and Burkholderia mallei are closely related gram-negative bacilli but differ significantly in biochemical characteristics, host range, and epidemiology.
  • A key biochemical test used to distinguish between them is the oxidase test:
    • pseudomallei: Oxidase positive, motile, and grows well on standard media like Ashdown's agar.
    • mallei: Oxidase variable (often weak or delayed), non-motile, and more fastidious in growth.
  • Other differentiating features include:
    • B. pseudomallei can ferment a broader range of sugars.
    • B. mallei is more host-specific and causes glanders, primarily in horses, while B. Pseudomallei causes melioidosis in a broader host range, including humans.
  • Thus, the oxidase test is a quick and useful method to differentiate these two organisms in a diagnostic microbiology lab.

List of important bacteria which are:

  • Catalase test: The catalase test detects the presence of the enzyme catalase, which breaks down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen.
    • Catalase positive: Remember: 'SPACE'
      • Staphylococcus aureus
      • Pseudomonas
      • Aspergillus
      • Candida
      • Enterobacter
  • Urease test: The urease test determines the ability of an organism to hydrolyse urea into ammonia and carbon dioxide, resulting in an alkaline environment.
    • Urease positive: Remember: 'PUNCH KiSS'
      • Proteus
      • Ureaplasma
      • Nocardia
      • Cryptococcus
      • Helicobacter
      • Klebsiella
      • Staph Saprophyticus
      • Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Oxidase test: A biochemical test that detects the presence of cytochrome c oxidase enzyme in bacteria, indicating aerobic respiration.
    • Oxidase negative:
      • All entero-bacteriacae
      • Acinetobacter
      • Staphylococci
      • Streptococci
  • Indole test: A biochemical test that determines a bacterium's ability to produce indole from the amino acid tryptophan using the enzyme tryptophanase.
    • Indole positive: Remember: 'Morgan the vulgar ox ate E. coli on the indole pasture with Ed'
      • Morganella
      • Proteus vulgaris
      • Klebsiella Oxytoca
      • Coli
      • Pasteurella
      • Edwardsiella

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is admitted to the ICU and has been on mechanical ventilation for the past 7 days following a road traffic accident. He develops fever, purulent tracheal secretions, and increasingly infiltrates on chest X-ray. Cultures from endotracheal aspirate grow a gram-negative coccobacillus that is oxidase-negative, non-motile, and shows multidrug resistance.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acinetobacter baumannii is the most common cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), particularly in ICU settings.

  • Acinetobacter baumannii is a gram-negative, oxidase-negative, non-fermenting, strictly aerobic coccobacillus that is notorious for causing hospital-acquired infections, particularly ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
  • It is especially prevalent in ICU settings where patients are intubated or have invasive devices.
  • It is highly resistant to multiple antibiotics and is known for surviving on hospital surfaces for prolonged periods.
  • A. baumannii is the most clinically relevant species in the Acinetobacter genus and is frequently isolated from VAP, bloodstream infections, and wound infections.

Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP):

  • It is a type of pneumonia that occurs in patients who are on mechanical ventilation for at least 48 hours.
  • It is a significant concern in critical care settings due to its association with increased morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs.
  • Causes and Risk Factors
    • Pathogens:VAP can be caused by a variety of bacteria, including:
      • Gram-negative bacteria:Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli.
      • Gram-positive bacteria:Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA) and streptococci.
      • Fungi and virusescan also contribute, but are less common.
    • Risk Factors:Factors that increase the risk of VAP include:
      • Prolonged mechanical ventilation.
      • Poor oral hygiene and dental health.
      • Supine positioning of the patient.
      • Advanced age and underlying chronic diseases.
      • Presence of tracheostomy.
      • Use of sedatives and neuromuscular blockers.

Explanation of other options:

Acinetobacter calcoaceticus (Option B): Less pathogenic; often grouped with A. baumannii as part of the A. calcoaceticus-A. baumannii complex, but baumannii is more virulent and common in VAP.

Acinetobacter lwoffii (Option C): A commensal species with low pathogenicity; not commonly associated with VAP.

Burkholderia cepacia (Option D): Primarily causes infections in cystic fibrosis or immunocompromised patients; not a typical cause of ventilator-associated pneumonia.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with rheumatic heart disease underwent mitral valve replacement and later developed fever and leukocytosis. A CT scan of the thorax revealed bilateral pleural effusion with basal lung collapse. Cultures showed non-lactose fermenting, mucoid, smooth colonies of motile Gram-negative rods that decarboxylated lysine but did not hydrolyse arginine. Which drug is this organism intrinsically resistant to?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Burkholderia cepacia, identified by its biochemical profile, is intrinsically resistant to polymyxins (e.g., polymyxin B and colistin).

  • The organism described is Burkholderia cepacia, a gram-negative, motile, non-lactose fermenter known for producing mucoid, smooth colonies, commonly associated with infections in immunocompromised hosts or those with structural lung diseases.
  • It decarboxylates lysine but does not hydrolyze arginine, a classic differentiating trait.
  • Burkholderia cepacia is notable for its intrinsic resistance to polymyxins-antibiotics that act by disrupting bacterial membranes.
  • This resistance is due to modifications in the bacterial outer membrane lipid A and efflux mechanisms.
  • B. cepacia is often resistant to polymyxin B and colistin, making these drugs ineffective in treatment.

Explanation of other options:

Cotrimoxazole (Option A): (Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is one of the preferred drugs for treating Burkholderia cepacia infections.

Meropenem (Option B): Burkholderia cepacia may exhibit variable sensitivity to carbapenems but is not intrinsically resistant to meropenem.

Doxycycline (Option C): May show some effectiveness against B. cepacia; it is not intrinsically resistant to it.

choices.text: Exotoxin A and B: Inhibition of EF2

questions.text: Among the various virulence factors found in Pseudomonas, which of the following is the most important factor, and what is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exotoxin A is the most important virulence factor of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and inhibits elongation factor-2 (EF-2), thereby blocking protein synthesis.

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic gram-negative bacillus notorious for causing nosocomial infections like ventilator-associated pneumonia, sepsis, and wound infections.
  • Its virulence is mediated by multiple factors such as pili, biofilm formation, pyocyanin, elastase, and various exotoxins.
  • Among these, Exotoxin A is considered the most critical virulence factor.
  • It acts by ADP-ribosylating EF-2 (elongation factor-2) in eukaryotic cells.
  • This post-translational modification irreversibly inactivates EF-2, halting translocation during protein synthesis and leading to cell death.
  • This mechanism is similar to diphtheria toxin.
  • This potent inhibition of host protein synthesis helps the bacteria evade immune responses and contributes to tissue necrosis and systemic toxicity.

Virulence Factors of Pseudomonas:

  • Pili or fimbriae (the organ of attachment) and polar flagellum (mediates chemotactic motility to reach the host’s surface).
  • Toxin-mediated immune evasion and tissue injury:
    • Non-Diffusible toxins (e.g., exotoxins S, U, T, and Y)
    • Diffusible toxins: For example, exotoxin A, proteases, phospholipases, hemolysins, elastases, pyocyanin, etc.
  • Exotoxin A: This is the most important virulence factor of P. aeruginosa. It inhibits protein synthesis
  • Pyo rubin
  • Pyo melanin
    • Alginate coat
    • Capsule
    • Biofilm formation
    • Wide temperature range
    • Mechanism of various bacterial toxins:
  • Inhibition of elongation factor 2:
    • Diphtheria toxin
    • Pseudomonas
  • Increase cAMP: Remember: 'CAEP'
    • Cholera
    • Anthrax
    • ETEC labile toxin
    • Pertussis
  • Increase cGMP:
    • ETEC stable toxin

questions.text: Identify the causative organism and its pigment leading to the above clinical picture.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa produces the blue-green pigment pyocyanin, which is a hallmark of its infections and contributes to tissue damage.

  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a non-fermenting, gram-negative bacillus known for causing hospital-acquired infections such as pneumonia, sepsis, and wound infections, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with prolonged hospitalization.
  • One of its characteristic features is the production of pigments, notably:
    • Pyocyanin: Blue-green pigment; generates reactive oxygen species, damages tissues, and impairs ciliary function.
    • Pyoverdine: Yellow-green pigment; acts as a siderophore for iron acquisition.
  • The blue-green discoloration of pus, sputum, or wound dressing in Pseudomonas infections is due to pyocyanin, which also helps distinguish it from other gram-negative bacteria.

Explanation of other options:

Serratia: Pyomelanin (Option A): Serratia marcescens typically produces red pigment (prodigiosin), not pyomelanin.

Chromobacterium: Pyoverdine (Option B): Chromobacterium violaceum produces violacein (purple pigment), not pyoverdine.

Mycobacterium: Pyomelanin (Option D): Mycobacteria are acid-fast organisms that do not produce pigments like pyomelanin.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old white female is presenting to the emergency department with acute-onset shortness of breath. Symptoms began approximately 2 days before and had progressively worsened with no associated, aggravating, or relieving factors noted. She had similar symptoms approximately 1 year ago with an acute, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation requiring hospitalization.
A physical exam reveals:
Temperature 103.3 F
Heart rate 88 bpm
Respiratory rate 30
BP 104/54
O2 saturation 90% on room air
The chest X-ray appeared as follows:

On culture: Large, opaque, irregular colonies with metallic sheen were found on Nutrient agar, and on peptone water surface pellicle was seen.
Which of the following is the most likely causative organism in the above patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrates. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is characterized by metallic sheen colonies, pellicle formation in liquid media, and frequently causes pneumonia in hospitalized or COPD patients.

  • This patient presents with signs of hospital-acquired or healthcare-associated pneumonia in the setting of underlying COPD-a condition that predisposes to Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection due to frequent antibiotic use, airway remodeling, and colonization.
  • Key microbiological clues supporting Pseudomonas:
  • Large, irregular colonies with metallic sheen on nutrient agar (due to pyocyanin and pyoverdin pigments)
    • Pellicle formation in peptone water (biofilm at the air-liquid interface due to its aerobic nature)
    • Frequently isolated in chronic lung diseases like COPD and cystic fibrosis
    • Tends to cause bronchopneumonia with patchy infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation
  • The high fever, tachypnea, hypoxia, and chest X-ray findings further support a severe bacterial pneumonia due to a virulent, aerobic gram-negative rod-hallmarks of Pseudomonas.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • It is notorious for causing infections at almost all sites; the most common being the lungs, skin, and soft tissues.
  • Chronic respiratory tract infections: It occurs in patients with underlying conditions that cause airway damage, such as cystic fibrosis or bronchiectasis. These infections are usually caused by mucoid strains of Pseudomonas.
  • Peptone water: Pseudomonas forms uniform turbidity with a surface pellicle formation, due to higher oxygen tension at the surface.
  • Nutrient agar: It produces large, opaque, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen (described as iridescence)
  • MacConkey medium: It forms non-lactose fermenting colonies.
  • Blood agar: Many strains are haemolytic on blood agar.
  • Pigments: Most strains produce diffusible pigments which are either blue-green (pyocyanin) or yellow-green (pyoverdine). Some strains are nonpigmented. Mostly colonies of Pseudomonas have a characteristic sweet ether or alcohol-like fruity odour.
  • Selective media: Cetrimide agar.
  • Enhancement media: King's media.
  • Diseases caused by Pseudomonas:
    • Shanghai fever
    • Malignant otitis externa (Swimmer's ear)
    • Ecthyma gangrenosum
    • Green nail syndrome
    • Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)-MCC
    • Endocarditis
    • In IV drug abusers, it leads to osteomyelitis
    • Burn wound infection
    • UTI
    • Meningitis
  • Anti-pseudomonal drugs:
    • Polymyxin B
    • Colistin
    • No resistance is reported till now with the above drugs.
    • Ceftriaxone and vancomycin are not antipseudomonal drugs.

For Pseudomonas-associated infections, think:

A)

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pseudomonas gives a metallic sheen, like iridescence green coloured colonies on Nutrient agar.

  • Nutrient agar: It produces large, opaque, irregular colonies with a metallic sheen (described as iridescence)
  • MacConkey medium: It forms non-lactose fermenting colonies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male patient presents to the emergency department with a fever, purulent wound drainage, and increasing pain in a recent surgical site following an open leg fracture repair. The wound has a greenish appearance, and the patient is experiencing difficulty breathing. On physical examination, the patient has signs of systemic infection, including tachycardia and hypotension. A wound culture grows blue-green colonies on selective agar. What is the most likely causative organism for this infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical presentations of the patient describe the most likely organism in this case as Pseudomonas infection. Pseudomonas is a monotrichous bacterium.

  • Points favouring the diagnosis are:
    • A greenish appearance of the wound at the recent surgical site was followed by an open leg fracture.
    • Wound culture on selective media like Cetrimide agar shows blue-green colonies.
  • Monotrichous(single polar flagellum), e.g., Vibrio cholerae, Pseudomonas, and Campylobacter.
  • Lophotrichous(multiple polar flagella), e.g,. Spirillum.
  • Peritrichous (flagella distributed over the entire cell surface), e.g., Salmonella Typhi, Escherichia coli.
  • Amphitrichous (single flagellum at both ends), e.g., Alcaligenes faecalis.

questions.text:
Which of the following special factors are required for Haemophilus?
A. Hemin
B. Christmas factor
C. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide
D. Fibrinogen
E. Thrombin
F. Ca2+
G. Fe2+
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Haemophilus species require Hemin (X factor) and NAD (V factor) for growth.

  • Haemophilus influenzae is a fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus that requires two key growth factors:
    • X factor = Hemin (a heat-stable iron-containing porphyrin, derived from hemoglobin)
    • V factor = NAD (Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide, a heat-labile coenzyme)
  • These factors are provided by chocolate agar, which is heated blood agar that lyses red blood cells to release both hemin and NAD.
  • On blood agar, growth may only occur near Staphylococcus aureus colonies due to satellitism, where S. aureus secretes NAD.
  • These growth requirements are essential for differentiating H. influenzae from other respiratory flora.
  • Growth surrounding X and XV disksonly: Produced by species that require X factor, but not V factor; examples include H. ducreyi and A. aphrophilus.
  • Growth surrounding V and XV disksonly: Produced by species that require V factor, but not X factor; examples include H. parainfluenzae, H. parahaemolyticus, and A. paraphrophilus.
  • Growth surrounding combined XV disk only: Produced by species that require both X and V factors; examples include: H. influenzae, H. aegyptius, and H. haemolyticus.

Other Factors:

  • Christmas factor: Also known as Factor IX, it is part of the coagulation cascade, not related to bacterial growth.
  • Fibrinogen: A plasma protein involved in clotting, not required for Haemophilus growth.
  • Thrombin: An enzyme in the coagulation pathway, unrelated to bacterial culture requirements.
  • Ca²⁺: Important in muscle contraction and clotting; Haemophilus does not require it for growth.
  • Fe²⁺: Iron is broadly important for many bacteria, but not specifically required for Haemophilus in culture media.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old male patient having multiple sex partners presented to your OPD with genital ulcers that are painful and bleed on touch. On clinical examination, the inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

What is the most likely diagnosis and its causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chancroid presents with painful, bleeding genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Chancroid is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the gram-negative bacillus Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • It is characterized by:
    • Painful genital ulcers that have ragged edges and bleed easily.
    • Soft chancre (in contrast to the hard chancre of syphilis).
    • Painful and unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy, which may suppurate and form buboes.
  • It is common in individuals with multiple sexual partners, and the risk is increased in settings with poor genital hygiene and coexisting STDs.
  • Diagnosis is often clinical, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • Microbiological confirmation can be made with culture or PCR (though not always widely available).

Explanation of other options:

Donovanosis: Klebsiella granulomatis (Option B): Painless, beefy-red ulcers that do not bleed on touch initially and no significant lymphadenopathy.

Genital herpes: Herpes simplex virus (Option C): Painful ulcers are usually multiple, but the ulcers are shallow and typically do not bleed on touch. Lymphadenopathy may be present but less tender.

Hard chancre: Syphilis (Option D): Painless ulcer with indurated base (hard chancre) and painless lymphadenopathy; not bleeding on touch.

questions.text:
Identify the unique features of the organism causing the following picture on X-ray in a 4-year-old child.

1) It is most commonly caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b.
2) The capsule of Hib has poly ribosyl inositol phosphate antigen.
3) Grows well on chocolate agar.
4) Shows Satellitism with Streptococcus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray in question shows a thumb sign suggestive of Epiglottitis. Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) is the most common cause of epiglottitis in children and grows well on chocolate agar.

  • Acute epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition most commonly seen in children and characterized radiologically by the "thumb sign" on lateral neck X-ray due to swollen epiglottis.
  • The most common causative agent is Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), especially in unvaccinated children.
  • Hib grows best on chocolate agar, which provides both X (hemin) and V (NAD) factors essential for its growth.
  • These two features - epiglottitis caused by Hib and growth on chocolate agar - are the correct unique characteristics in this case.

Epiglottitis:

  • It is a cellulitis of the epiglottis and supraglottic tissues. It is life-threatening as it can lead to acute airway obstruction. It typically affects older children (2-7 years old) and rarely adults.
  • Influenzae serotype b (Hib) is the most virulent among all types and accounts for most of the invasive infections.
  • Hib capsule has a unique chemical structure, made up of polyribosyl ribitol phosphate(PRP) antigen.
  • It is strongly immunogenic, induces IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies, which are bactericidal, opsonic, and protective. Hence, PRP antigen is used for vaccination.
  • It grows well on chocolate agar. While preparing chocolate agar, blood is poured into molten agar at 75°C, which causes lysis of RBCs, releasing an excess of factor V. Hence, it supports the growth of H. influenzae.

Satellitism:

  • influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided.
  • When aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, factor V is released from S. aureus.
  • Therefore, it forms larger colonies adjacent to the S. aureus streak line, and the size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line.
  • This phenomenon is called satellitism, a property that is routinely employed for the isolation of H. influenzae.

Diseases caused by H. influenzae are categorised into two groups:

  • Invasive: Caused by Hib (Haemophilus influenzae type b).
    • Meningitis
    • Pneumonia
    • Epiglottitis
    • Septic arthritis
    • Endocarditis
  • Non-invasive: Caused by non-typeable Haemophilus
    • Otitis
    • Sinusitis
    • Acute exacerbation of COPD
  • Vaccine:
    • Usually aged <2 years, conjugated vaccine is preferred, since conjugated vaccine elicits a high immune response (PCV13).
    • 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide (PPSV-23) vaccine is not recommended for children below 2 years. It is used for adults and children above 5 years of age.

choices.text: It is the most common causative agent in this child
It frequently leads to invasive systemic disease
An effective conjugate vaccine is available for it

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, ear pain, and irritability. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane is bulging and erythematous, consistent with acute otitis media. You are asked to determine the likely strain of Haemophilus influenzae responsible and differentiate between type b (Hib) and nontypeable strains. Which of the following is most likely in favour of a non-typeable strain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-typeable Haemophilus influenzae (NTHi) is the most common cause of localized infections like otitis media, unlike type b strains, which are associated with invasive disease.

  • Haemophilus influenzae exists in encapsulated (types a-f) and non-encapsulated (non-typeable) forms.
  • Type b (Hib) is encapsulated and known for causing invasive diseases like meningitis, epiglottitis, and septicemia.
  • Nontypeable strains lack a capsule and are not covered by the Hib vaccine.
  • They do not cause invasive disease but are major causes of localized infections such as:
    • Otitis media
    • Sinusitis
    • Exacerbations of COPD
  • In this case, the child presents with otitis media, which is typically due to non-typeable strains of H. influenzae, not Hib.

Explanation of other options:

It typically causes hematogenous dissemination (Option B): Describes H. influenzae type b (Hib), not nontypeable strains.

It frequently leads to invasive systemic disease (Option C): Again, invasive disease is a hallmark of encapsulated Hib, not nontypeable strains.

An effective conjugate vaccine is available for it (Option D): The Hib vaccine is only effective against type b strains; no vaccine exists for nontypeable strains.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy came to the Pediatrics OPD with complaints of low-grade fever, cough, and vomiting. His vitals are normal, and growth is appropriate for his age. On examination, the boy coughs 10 times in a row with a typical sound at the end. His parents do not believe in getting him vaccinated, stating that vaccines are for weak people and that their son is the strongest person. Which of the following media is used to isolate the given bacteria?
i. PPLO agar
ii. Bordet-Gengou agar
iii. PLET media
iv. Regan Lowe media
v. Pike's media
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough, is isolated using Bordet-Gengou agar and Regan-Lowe medium, which are selective for this fastidious organism.

  • The clinical scenario describes whooping cough (pertussis) caused by Bordetella pertussis, especially in an unvaccinated child.
  • This Gram-negative coccobacillus is highly fastidious, requiring enriched and selective media for isolation.
  • Bordet-Gengou agar: Contains potato infusion, glycerol, and blood; selective by addition of antibiotics like methicillin. It supports the growth of Bordetella pertussis.
  • Regan-Lowe medium: A charcoal agar medium with horse blood and cephalexin; more commonly used today than Bordet-Gengou due to better sensitivity.
  • Both are used in clinical microbiology labs to grow B. pertussis from nasopharyngeal swabs.
  • PPLO agar: Used for Mycoplasma pneumoniae, not Bordetella pertussis.
  • PLET medium: Selective medium for Bacillus anthracis.
  • Pike's medium: Transport medium used for Streptococcus pyogenes, not suitable for B. pertussis.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of toxin produced by Bordetella Pertussis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bordetella pertussis toxin, P, T is produced by - Increase cAMP mechanism.

  • Bordetella pertussis is also known as the 100-day cough.
  • Causes: whooping cough/pertussis.
  • Clinical features: 3 phases
    • Catarrhal: Dry cough, fever, puts maximum infectivity.
      • It lasts for 1-2 weeks and is characterized by common cold-like nonspecific symptoms, such as coryza, lacrimation, mild cough, low-grade fever, and malaise. It is a highly infectious stage. In this stage, both smear and culture are likely to be positive.
    • Paroxysmal: whooping cough.
      • This stage lasts for 1-6 weeks. Patients are less infectious; smear and culture may become negative. It is characterized by specific symptoms, such as whooping cough and post-tussive vomiting.
    • Convalescent: recovery stage.
      • This stage lasts for 1-3 months. It occurs following the paroxysmal stage, during which the frequency and severity of coughing gradually decrease. Antibodies may appear in serum.
  • Culture media:
    • Bordet Gengou medium
    • Charcoal agar
  • Colony appearance:
    • Bisected pearls/mercury drops
    • Aluminum paint appearance(confluent).
    • Thumbprint appearance.

Mechanism of various bacterial toxins:

  • Inhibition of elongation factor 2:
    • Diphtheria toxin
    • Pseudomonas
  • Increase cAMP: Remember: 'CAEP'
    • Cholera
    • Anthrax
    • ETEC labile toxin
    • Pertussis
  • Increase cGMP:
    • ETEC stable toxin

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought by parents with a history of cough with characteristic inspiratory whoop. The child is not immunized. Which of the following would be the best method of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nasopharyngeal swab is the best specimen for isolation of Bordetella pertussis, the causative organism of whooping cough.

  • Whooping cough (pertussis) is caused by Bordetella pertussis, a Gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • It typically presents with a paroxysmal cough followed by an inspiratory "whoop" and is most severe in unimmunized children.
  • For microbiological diagnosis, the ideal specimen is a nasopharyngeal swab or nasopharyngeal aspirate, as B. pertussis colonizes the ciliated respiratory epithelium of the nasopharynx.
  • The swab should be taken using Dacron or calcium alginate swabs (not cotton) and transported in Regan-Lowe medium.
  • Culture, PCR, and direct fluorescent antibody staining can be done from this sample.

Explanation of other options:

Cough plate culture (Option B): This is an outdated method where the child coughs directly onto a culture plate, but it's not practical or sensitive compared to nasopharyngeal swabs.

Per oral (Option C): Oral secretions are not ideal as B. pertussis resides in the nasopharynx and not the oropharynx.

Endotracheal aspirate (Option D): This is invasive and reserved for intubated patients. It's not appropriate for routine diagnosis in a conscious, non-intubated child.

questions.text:
Acellular pertussis vaccine is composed of:
a) Pertussis toxoid
b) FHA
c) Pertactin
d) IgA
e) Adhesins
f) cAMP
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The acellular pertussis vaccine contains purified antigens-pertussis toxoid, filamentous hemagglutinin (FHA), and pertactin-that elicit protective immunity.

  • Acellular pertussis (aP) vaccines were developed to reduce the adverse effects seen with whole-cell pertussis vaccines.
  • These vaccines include purified, inactivated components of Bordetella pertussis.
  • The main components typically used are:
    • Pertussis toxoid (a): A detoxified form of pertussis toxin, which is immunogenic and crucial for protection.
    • FHA (Filamentous Hemagglutinin) (b): An adhesin involved in bacterial attachment to the ciliated respiratory epithelium.
    • Pertactin (c): An outer membrane protein that also acts as an adhesin and enhances immunogenicity.
  • These components stimulate the immune system to recognize and fight the actual bacteria during future infections.
  • IgA: This is an immunoglobulin produced by the host's mucosal immune system; not a vaccine component.
  • Adhesins: While FHA and pertactin are adhesins and part of the vaccine, this option is too vague and doesn't refer to any specific purified antigen beyond what's already included in a, b, and c.
  • cAMP: Cyclic AMP is a secondary messenger involved in the toxin's mechanism, but is not used as a vaccine antigen.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant presents with a persistent cough lasting several weeks, initially resembling a cold. The mother reports the child has missed standard vaccinations due to her anti-vaccination beliefs. The infant has been kept home from daycare, and tests confirm whooping cough (pertussis). What is the drug of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Erythromycin is the drug of choice for treating Bordetella pertussis infection, especially in infants under 1 year.

  • Pertussis (whooping cough) is caused by Bordetella pertussis, a Gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • In unvaccinated children, it commonly presents with a catarrhal phase followed by the characteristic paroxysmal coughing with inspiratory "whoop".
  • The drug of choice for treatment (and prophylaxis) is a macrolide, most commonly erythromycin, especially for infants under 1 year.
  • Erythromycin not only helps reduce symptoms if given early (during the catarrhal phase), but more importantly, it reduces transmission by eliminating the organism from the nasopharynx.
  • Alternatives include azithromycin or clarithromycin, especially in older children or those who cannot tolerate erythromycin.
  • Cotrimoxazole can be used in macrolide-intolerant cases but is not first-line.

Explanation of other options:

Cotrimoxazole (Option A): Although it is a second-line option for pertussis, it is not the first-line drug of choice, especially in infants.

Ceftazidime (Option C): A third-generation cephalosporin primarily used for Pseudomonas and Gram-negative infections; not effective against B. pertussis.

Nitrofurantoin (Option D): Used only for urinary tract infections; it has no role in respiratory tract infections or pertussis.

questions.text: Match the correct pairs of species of Brucella with the host it infects:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nomen species: Important nomen species associated with human infections are as follows:

  • A. melitensis: It is usually pathogenic to sheep, goat, and camels. Man is also a susceptible host
  • B. abortus: The infection is acquired from cattle and buffalo
  • C. suis: It infects pigs most often.
  • D. canis: It causes abortion in dogs. Occasional cases of human infection have been reported.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman who worked as a research assistant in a veterinary microbiology laboratory complained of intermittent fever, anorexia, profuse sweating, malaise, headache, normotension, and muscle pain, especially of the neck and shoulder, and arthralgia for 3 days. She was one of the 7 laboratory workers who were involved in research on the isolation of B. melitensis from goats for the past 6 months. Which of the following is not the mode of transmission of this organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brucella species are transmitted via direct contact, ingestion of contaminated animal products, or inhalation-but vertical (mother-to-child) transmission is not a recognized mode.

  • Brucella melitensis is a Gram-negative, facultative intracellular coccobacillus known for causing brucellosis, a zoonotic infection.
  • It is particularly virulent among Brucella species and is often acquired through occupational exposure in lab workers, veterinarians, and farmers.
  • Modes of transmission include:
    • Direct contact with infected animals or tissues (through skin abrasions or mucosal surfaces)
    • Foodborne transmission through consumption of unpasteurized dairy products (especially goat cheese and milk)
    • Airborne transmission via inhalation of infectious aerosols, especially in laboratory settings
  • However, vertical transmission (transplacental or perinatal spread from mother to child) is not considered a common or significant route for Brucella transmission in humans.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not used for diagnosing brucellosis in animals?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard agglutination test (SAT) is used for diagnosing brucellosis in humans, not in animals.

  • Brucellosis in animals is commonly diagnosed using serological tests that are easy to perform, rapid, and suitable for field conditions.
  • The commonly used animal tests include:
    • Milk Ring Test (MRT): A screening test to detect Brucella antibodies in milk samples from cows and buffaloes. Positive tests show a bluish ring at the cream layer. (Option A ruled out)
    • Rose Bengal Card Test (RBCT): A rapid slide agglutination test using stained Brucella antigen; widely used for serodiagnosis in both animals and humans. (Option B ruled out)
    • Whey Agglutination Test: A test done on whey (the liquid portion of milk after curdling) for the detection of Brucella antibodies in milk-producing animals. (Option D ruled out)
    • The Standard Agglutination Test (SAT), however, is primarily used for diagnosing brucellosis in humans, not animals. It measures total agglutinating antibodies (IgM and IgG) and is performed on serum samples using serial dilutions.

questions.text: What is the WHO regimen for Brucellosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

WHO recommends a 6-week combination of doxycycline and rifampicin as the standard treatment for uncomplicated brucellosis.

  • According to the World Health Organization, the preferred regimen for treating uncomplicated brucellosis in adults is:
    • Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 6 weeks, plus
    • Rifampicin 600-900 mg once daily for 6 weeks
  • This combination is effective in preventing relapse, reducing the intracellular burden of Brucella, and addressing complications.
  • The rationale behind this regimen lies in the intracellular location of Brucella spp., necessitating drugs with good intracellular penetration like doxycycline and rifampicin.
  • In complicated cases (e.g., spondylitis, endocarditis), aminoglycosides like streptomycin or gentamicin may be added during the initial 1-2 weeks for synergistic effect.

Explanation of other options:

Gentamicin + doxycycline (Option B): Used in some severe or complicated cases but not the standard WHO-recommended regimen.

Ceftriaxone + doxycycline (Option C): Ceftriaxone is not standard for brucellosis and is mainly reserved for neurobrucellosis or children.

Rifampicin + gentamicin + doxycycline (Option D): Overly aggressive for standard treatment; may be used in specific complicated or relapse cases, but not WHO's standard recommendation.

questions.text: Identify the correct statement regarding the Serum Agglutination Test (SAT) in Brucellosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The prozone phenomenon in SAT for brucellosis may lead to false-negative results due to excess antibodies interfering with agglutination.

  • Serum Agglutination Test (SAT) is a standard serological test for diagnosing human brucellosis.
  • It detects antibodies, mainly IgM and IgG, against Brucella antigens.
  • A common limitation is the prozone phenomenon, where an excess of antibodies prevents proper lattice formation, leading to false-negative results.
  • This phenomenon is especially important to consider during acute brucellosis, where antibody titers are very high.
  • It can be resolved by serial dilution of the serum, which reveals the true agglutination titer.
  • In contrast, 2-mercaptoethanol (2-ME) SAT is used to differentiate acute (IgM-mediated) from chronic (IgG-mediated) brucellosis.
  • 2-ME destroys IgM, so if SAT is positive and 2-ME SAT is negative, it suggests acute infection.
  • If both are positive, it may indicate chronic or ongoing infection.

Explanation of other options:

Presence of blocking antibodies gives a false positive result in SAT (Option B): (Incorrect) Blocking antibodies like non-agglutinating IgA/IgG can mask true agglutination, leading to false negatives, not false positives.

SAT is used to diagnose Brucellosis in animals (Option C): (Incorrect) SAT is used for human diagnosis. In animals, the Milk Ring Test, Rose Bengal Test, or Complement Fixation Test are more commonly used.

SAT positive and 2-mercaptoethanol SAT positive indicates an acute infection (Option D): (Incorrect) In acute infection, only SAT is positive; 2-ME SAT is usually negative because it destroys IgM. If both are positive, it suggests chronic or ongoing infection.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is required for the isolation of F. tularensis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Francisella tularensis requires cysteine-enriched media for growth due to its fastidious nature.

  • Francisella tularensis is a highly fastidious, facultative intracellular bacterium that causes tularemia.
  • It requires enriched media containing cysteine for primary isolation, as it cannot synthesize this amino acid independently.
  • Commonly used media include:
    • Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar
    • Cysteine Heart Agar with blood
    • Chocolate agar supplemented with cysteine
  • The organism does not grow well on standard media like blood agar or MacConkey agar without cysteine supplementation.
  • This characteristic is critical for its laboratory diagnosis and also distinguishes it from other gram-negative coccobacilli.

Explanation of other options:

Glycine (Option A): Not required for F. tularensis growth; it is not a key growth factor for this organism.

Lysine (Option C): While essential in protein synthesis, it is not the limiting factor for F. tularensis growth in culture.

Glutamic acid (Option D): Not specifically required for F. tularensis isolation; it plays no special role in enhancing its growth in vitro.

choices.text: Tularaemia, treat with streptomycin or gentamicin

questions.text: A 34-year-old man who works as a hunter presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of fever, chills, malaise, and a painful swelling in his right axilla. He mentions that he recently skinned a rabbit he had hunted. On physical examination, there is a tender, erythematous, and fluctuant lymph node in the right axillary region. His white blood cell count is elevated. A Gram stain of the lymph node aspirate shows small Gram-negative coccobacilli. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Handling of wild rabbits leading to ulceroglandular lymphadenitis with gram-negative coccobacilli suggests Francisella tularensis infection, treated with aminoglycosides like streptomycin or gentamicin.

  • This patient presents with ulceroglandular tularemia, the most common form of the disease caused by Francisella tularensis, a facultative intracellular gram-negative coccobacillus.
  • The infection is typically transmitted through contact with wild animals, especially rabbits or ticks, and hunters are particularly at risk.
  • The key features pointing to tularemia include:
    • Painful, swollen lymph nodes (buboes)
    • Fever and constitutional symptoms
    • Small gram-negative coccobacilli on Gram stain
  • The most effective treatment is with aminoglycosides, particularly streptomycin (drug of choice) or gentamicin.
  • Alternatives like doxycycline or ciprofloxacin can be used in mild cases, but aminoglycosides are preferred for severe disease.

Explanation of other options:

Anthrax, treated with doxycycline (Option A): Anthrax typically presents with a painless eschar and is caused by Bacillus anthracis, a large gram-positive rod, not a gram-negative coccobacillus.

Bubonic plague, treated with ciprofloxacin (Option B): Yersinia pestis also presents with buboes and is a gram-negative coccobacillus, but is associated with rat fleas and urban exposure, not rabbit hunting.

Leptospirosis, treated with amoxicillin (Option D): Leptospirosis is caused by a spirochete, Leptospira interrogans, and typically follows exposure to contaminated water, not animal skinning. It also does not present with localized lymphadenitis.

questions.text: A researcher studying zoonotic diseases wants to understand the virulence factors of Brucella species. What characteristic of Brucella contributes to its ability to evade the immune response?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brucella evades the immune system primarily by surviving and replicating within macrophages.

  • Brucella species are facultative intracellular pathogens.
  • They have a unique ability to survive and multiply within phagocytic cells, particularly macrophages.
  • This intracellular lifestyle enables the bacteria to avoid humoral immune defenses and establish a chronic infection.
  • Brucella uses specialized virulence mechanisms, such as Type IV secretion systems, to manipulate host cell processes and avoid phagolysosomal fusion, allowing it to persist within the intracellular niche.

Explanation of other options:

Production of exotoxins (Option A): Brucella does not produce classical exotoxins; its pathogenesis is primarily due to intracellular survival rather than toxin-mediated damage.

Formation of biofilms (Option C): While biofilm formation is a virulence factor in some bacteria, it is not a primary mechanism used by Brucella to evade immunity.

High mutation rate (Option D): Brucella is not known for a particularly high mutation rate; its immune evasion is related to intracellular persistence, not genetic variability.
